journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part P: Journal of Sports Engineering and Technology

title-group.article-title: The validation of a three-dimensional ball rotation model

article-meta.aff: 1School of Sport Science, Exercise and Health, The University of Western Australia, Australia
3Vicon Motion Systems Ltd, Oxford Metrics Group, UK

author-notes.corresp: David Whiteside, School of Sport Science, Exercise and Health, The University of Western Australia, 35 Stirling Highway, Crawley, Western Australia 6009, Australia. Email: david.whiteside@gmail.com

abstract.p: With the development of three-dimensional motion analysis systems, methods for accurately tracking and modelling three-dimensional body kinematics have evolved and are well established. Comparatively, the methodologies involved in tracking ball flight have failed to utilize three-dimensional motion analysis, hence this proposal of a new model. A 12-camera VICON MX motion analysis system captured the kinematics of three sports balls rotating on the end of a drill. The balls were positioned in three orientations and spun at three speeds in each. Comparing differences between: (a) the modelled spin axis of the ball with that of the fixed drill bit about which it was rotating, and (b) the rotation rate of the modelled ball with the stable waveform of a marker thereon, revealed the validity of the proposed ball model. These differences were found to be minimal, suggesting that the proposed ball model is an advancement of its predecessors.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Many sports involve the use of a ball, be it to score goals in soccer, pitch strikeouts in baseball or shoot free throws in basketball. Moreover, the flight characteristics of these balls play a major role in determining the outcome of the skill at hand. It is for this reason that the study of ball motion and aerodynamics has received much attention in sporting literature. However, this research has been restricted, almost exclusively, to wind tunnel testing or analysis in two dimensions.1 –5 While the implications of this research are relevant to the sporting domain, there are practical limitations and accuracy issues involved with these methods.

In the past decade, three-dimensional (3D) motion analysis systems have become the gold standard for analysing human motion. Methodologies for accurately tracking and modelling 3D body kinematics have evolved and are now well established. The evolution of ball tracking methods has not followed suit as, perplexingly, a dearth of research in this area has employed contemporary motion capture technology. With technological trends driving the widespread use of 3D motion capture, it is logical that scientists use these systems to analyse ball flight in the same way they are used to analyse the human body. The literature provides ample evidence of the evolution of ball tracking methods throughout history, and suggests that it is now time to take the next step.

Copious research has investigated the aerodynamics of sports balls. These studies have described the physics of ball flight, namely how surface properties or spin produce deviations in a ball’s trajectory.6–8 Wind tunnel research has described fluid mechanics,9 and how a ball’s trajectory is influenced by the orientation of its spin axis.1 This work has some practical implications for coaches and players, namely in those sports which involve the intentional alteration of ball’s trajectory to deceive opponents (i.e. baseball pitching or cricket bowling) or overcome constraints (i.e. the defensive wall in soccer or the net in tennis). Unfortunately, since this work is scarcely extended to measurement in real-world sporting scenarios, the ecological validity of these findings is limited.

Subsequent to wind tunnel research, much work has attempted to enhance understanding by describing ball flight during the performance of actual sporting skills. In tennis, ball flight has been assessed in tournament settings using high speed cameras, ultimately distinguishing pre- and post-impact characteristics in different types of strokes.2,10,11 Similarly, tracking the ball in volleyball has added a new dimension to perception–action coupling in sport, with the discovery of temporal relationships between the ball and body.12 These findings have direct implications for athletes and underline the importance of tracking ball flight in throwing and striking skills.

Focusing on the characteristics of ball flight, ball velocity provides a critical outcome measure in numerous sports and, fittingly, has been afforded much attention in sports research. Digital video footage3,13,14 and radar guns15–17are examples of how ball velocity has been measured previously. However these methods, in particular those involving the radar gun, are susceptible to significant measurement errors. Even at sufficient sampling rates, two-dimensional video footage can only measure planar kinematics. Additionally, radar guns provide accurate readings only when the gun is directed along the line of ball flight – a situation that is not possible if the ball is curving in the air. Perhaps of most importance is an appreciation that not all sporting skills require maximal effort, rendering this measure less valuable in such cases. Specifically, sports such as soccer, baseball, cricket and tennis, require the athlete to impart spin to the ball. In these cases, the ability to measure ball velocity alongside the kinematics of ball spin is of more relevance.

Though unable to directly measure rotational kinematics, newer systems do provide improved tracking of ball flight during professional matches. In this way, the ball’s velocity and curved trajectory can be measured concurrently. The Hawk-Eye system, part of the adjudication process in professional tennis and cricket, uses six cameras sampling at 106 Hz to track the 3D position of the ball with an accuracy of < 5 mm. The PITCHf/x system does the same in Major League Baseball using two orthogonal 60 Hz cameras mounted in the stadium. This system tracks ball position with an accuracy of < 24 mm. The data provided by these systems describes the ball velocities and deviation involved in several different sporting skills. Though these systems provide valuable information, from a scientific perspective they do not overcome the frame rate issue and are unable to directly measure angular velocity.

Appreciating the importance of ball spin in several sports, more comprehensive research has attempted to describe the rotational axis of a spinning ball. Jinji and Sakurai recreated the spin axis and rotation rate of a baseball by digitizing marks on the ball using five digital cameras.4 To their credit, researchers have validated these methods to reassure any applications manifesting from the research. Although scientifically sound, the relatively low sampling rate of some digital video recorders can render this method vulnerable to aliasing effects, namely during the investigation of high-speed movements. This is not always the case, as more modern cameras have been used to collect data while sampling at 1000 Hz.11 However, the digitization process associated with these techniques is sometimes deemed laborious compared to contemporary alternatives, where the majority of processing is automated. The evolution of motion capture has bestowed upon us systems capable of tracking 3D marker positions automatically with an error margin less than 0.1 mm.18–20 Unsurprisingly, such systems have become commonplace in human movement laboratories. With these systems already driving movement research, it seems illogical to capture body kinematics and ball flight separately if their conjunctional measurement is possible. This would allow their subsequent processing to be completed concurrently and maximize the consistency between the measures.

Two investigations have taken the first steps toward incorporating 3D motion capture systems in the measurement of ball flight in sport. Focusing on the flight of baseballs, Alaways and Hubbard21 were the first to utilize a 3D motion capture system to comprehensively measure the rotational kinematics of ball flight. Measuring the rotational motion of four pieces of retro reflective tape on the baseball’s surface allowed the angular velocity of the ball to be quantified. Griffiths and colleagues tracked four markers attached to a soccer ball in three dimensions, successfully recreating a spin axis and calculating angular velocity.22 A minimum tetrahedral arrangement of markers, at specific locations on the ball, was deemed necessary to calculate relevant ball flight variables. While neither of these studies was directly validated, they attest to methods of potentially measuring 3D characteristics of ball flight in ecologically relevant settings.

The direct application of ball flight research illustrates how its measurement can be just as useful to a coach as the highly sought after body kinematics. Logically, information garnered from the ball effects a greater understanding of its role in a sporting skill, yielding practical applications. Most applicable to coaches is the understanding of how a ball travels through the air and how this flight influences the goal of the skill. Namely, this involves defining the absolute velocity of the ball, the axis about which the ball rotates and the angular velocity at which it does so. Only then can one decisively hypothesize how body mechanics influence ball flight, and tailor training interventions accordingly. With this in mind, the unprecedented aim of this study was to validate a 3D modelling technique capable of measuring these critical ball flight variables inside a 3D motion capture environment.

sec.title: Materials and protocol
sec.p: In this study, a tennis ball, a cricket ball and a soccer ball were affixed to a drill bit and rotated thereon. Drill bits were driven through the centre of the tennis and cricket balls and affixed using adhesive. Since puncturing the bladder of the soccer ball was not possible a plastic copolymer drill bit was crafted to symmetrically clasp the ball and permit rotation. A Wilson Australian Open tennis ball, a regulation men’s Kookaburra Cricket ball and a size 5 FIFA approved soccer ball were used.

Three ultra-light, foam hemispherical markers with a radius of 7 mm and mass <0.07 g were fixed to each ball using double-sided tape with a thickness of ≈ 0.01 cm (Figure 1). Three spherical markers, 14 mm in diameter were affixed to the drill, allowing a 3D coordinate system (CS) to be created therein.

caption.p: Positions of markers and orientation of coordinate system axes.

sec.p: With the ball attached, the drill was positioned in three different orientations (pointing forward (FO), ≈ 45° (45) and sideways (SO)) and spun at three different speeds (slow ≈ 2.5 revs.s−1; medium ≈ 6.5 revs.s−1; and fast ≈ 21 revs.s−1) in each orientation. Knuckleball pitches in baseball have been speculated to have low rotation rates, similar to the slow speed.23 The medium (med) speed was chosen as it reflects previously noted angular velocities of a soccer ball in a free kick,24,25 while the fastest speed is more representative of those found in cricket spin bowling and the tennis serve.26,27 Markers attached to the drill and ball were tracked in three dimensions using a 12-camera Vicon MX motion analysis system operating at 500 Hz (Oxford Metrics, UK). Twenty five frames of data were analysed in each condition as this was deemed to represent the minimum amount of ball flight one would expect to capture in sporting skills.

Raw data were filtered using a Woltring filter28 at an established mean squared error (MSE) of 2 mm following a numerical residual analysis used in conjunction with visual inspection of the raw versus filtered trajectories.

sec.title: Defining the drill coordinate system
sec.p:
A drill model was written specifically for this study. Two markers were placed strategically on its superior surface, one at the posterior end (DPOS) and one at the anterior end (DANT), carefully aligned along its anatomical length guided by surface lines on the drill. A further marker (DINF) placed orthogonally on the inferior aspect of the drill frame, allowed the construction of a 3D CS (Table 1). Within the drill CS, the vector created from DPOST to DANT represented the direction in which the drill bit was pointing. Since the drill bit was driven thorough the centre of the ball, it also represented the spin axis of the ball. In this way, the methodical placement of the drill markers meant that the
y
-axis of the drill CS was aligned with the drill bit and, in turn, corresponded to the spin axis of the ball (Figure 1).

caption.p: Definition of the drill and ball coordinate systems.

tr.td: The midpoint of the DANT and DPOST markers

y

axes

fn.p: DANT, DPOST, DINF: drill markers; BAL1, BAL2, BAL3: ball markers.

sec.title: Defining the ball coordinate system
sec.p: The ball model relies on the creation of a CS, with an origin at the centre of the ball. The location of the centre of the ball is, therefore, essential to these calculations, and accurate modelling of this location is critical. The circumference of each ball was measured and two markers (BAL1 and BAL3) were placed on opposite poles of the ball. Taking the average 3D displacement of the polar markers (BAL1 and BAL3) is a straightforward method of determining the centre of the ball (BALO). The third marker (BAL2) was placed approximately orthogonal to these to complete the CS (Table 1). A plane intersecting a sphere’s centre will split it into two equal hemispheres. Therefore, as long as two markers are on opposite poles, the third marker can be placed arbitrarily to produce an aforementioned plane between the three markers. In this way, the cross-product of the vector from BALO to BAL2 and the vector from the BAL3 to BAL1 will always produce a right-hand CS, with an origin in the centre of the ball.

sec.title: Calculating the ball coordinate system’s 3D angular velocity vector
sec.p: 3D measurement of rotation expresses the orientation of a moving CS relative to a reference CS. In biomechanics, this often involves a distal segment relative to the adjacent segment (i.e. the hand CS relative to the forearm CS describes rotation at the wrist). During flight however, the ball is not attached to a fixed object relative to which its rotations can be expressed. Therefore, expressing the angular velocity relative to the fixed global CS is the most appropriate method for describing ball rotation. Preceding this, the angular velocity of the ball CS must be calculated.

From the above, the angular velocity about each axis of the ball CS (

) can be calculated using dot products. Specifically, a unit vector is multiplied by time derivative of another to project an angular velocity vector on the orthogonal axis

The angular velocity components calculated from equation (2) describe three angular velocities – one about each axis of the ball CS. The ball angular velocity vector can be thought of as the unique vector within the ball CS that remains constant as the ball rotates (i.e. the spin axis). Therefore, it follows that the components from equation (2) be combined to produce the absolute angular velocity vector (

sec.title: Interpreting the angular velocity vector using spherical coordinates
sec.p:
Converting the Cartesian coordinates of the angular velocity vector to spherical coordinates provides a simple method of making the spin axis ‘reader friendly’. From the Cartesian coordinates of a point
( x , y , z )
, its spherical coordinates
( r , θ , φ )
can be obtained using rudimentary geometry (Table 2). This becomes relevant since the Cartesian coordinates of the angular velocity vector (
ω
→
) in the global CS have already been established in equation (4). Therefore, the spherical conversions can describe the angular velocity vector as two separate deviations from the
x

θ
is its orthogonal projection from the
xy

φ
is the angle between the
x

xy
plane (Figure 2).

Measured from the fixed reference that is the

sec.title: Calculation of ball diameter
sec.p: The analysis system operates by tracking the 3D coordinates of the centre of spherical markers. This provides a straightforward method for calculating ball diameter since the spherical centre of a hemispherical marker attached to the surface of the ball corresponds to the ball surface. This allows ball diameter to be calculated as the length of the vector between two polar markers. In this way, ball diameter can be measured without the need for remedial calculations (as would be required if spherical markers or pieces of tape were used). Ensuring that the modelled diameter reflects the known diameter of the sports ball in question provides validation for subsequent calculations.

sec.title: Validating the model
sec.p:
Since the ball was rotating around a stable axis fixed to the stationary drill, displacement curves of the ball markers were cyclical. Referring to Figure 3 and observing BAL1, the marker is initially positioned on the inferior aspect of the ball where its vertical displacement is obviously smallest. A quarter (90°) rotation of the ball displaced the marker in an upward direction to point B. Peak vertical displacement of the marker occurred at point C when the ball had rotated 180° and was the furthest distance from its original position. After this peak, the continued rotation of the ball compelled the marker downwards in the vertical plane through point D until it had returned to its starting position at point E. From this, it is evident how each marker moved in a circle as the ball rotated, ultimately returning to its original spatial location before rotating again. Therefore, the displacement of a given marker in the vertical plane (i.e. along the
z
-axis), relative to time, was portrayed as a stable sine wave. True rotations of the ball were apparent from the waveform, in that one period (
T
) corresponded to one full rotation of the ball. In the slow and medium speed conditions, the 25 frames of data analysed were not enough to capture a full period. In these cases data outside of the 25 frames were examined solely for the purposes of determining one period (measured in seconds). Dividing one second by the period indicated the rotation rate of the ball as revolutions per second.

As previously established, the
y
-axis of the drill CS corresponded to the true spin axis of the ball. Therefore, the drill CS rotations about its
x
and
z
axes represented the true elevation and azimuth angles of the ball’s spin axis, respectively.

sec.title: Measuring the error of the modelled outputs
Results
sec.p: The diameter of the ball, calculated as the distance between BAL1 and BAL3 was measured across the entire trial (Figure 4). The mean diameters for the tennis, cricket and soccer balls were 6.68 ± 0.05 cm, 7.33 ± 0.03 cm and 21.96 ± 0.05 cm, respectively. The ranges of the diameter calculations across the entire trial were 0.15 cm (tennis ball), 0.08 cm (cricket ball) and 0.17 cm (soccer ball).

caption.p: Ball diameter as measured by the ball model across an entire typical trial for the three balls.

sec.p: The absolute difference between the modelled and true spin axes and rotation rates are depicted as error scores in Table 3. The error in the elevation angle was similar across balls and speeds with an average error of 0.83 ± 0.74°. All errors in the elevation angle were smaller than 2.38°. Eighteen of the 27 error scores recorded for the elevation angle were smaller than 1.00°. Errors in the azimuth angle were also small, with an average of 1.14 ± 0.89°. Fifteen of the azimuth angle errors were smaller than 1.00°, the largest error being 2.99°. Error scores reported for the rotation rate of the ball were minimal with the average error across balls and orientations being 0.02 ± 0.02 rev.s–1.

caption.p: Modelled, true and error measures for the spin axis and angular velocity measures.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The low standard deviation of each ball’s modelled diameter represents the high consistency of this modelled output and can be used as an indicator of data quality.22 The marker placement appears to permit accurate measurement of the ball’s diameter and, in turn, the centre of each ball. The low standard deviations suggest that the centre of the ball is being precisely modelled, allowing subsequent outputs to be interpreted with confidence. Additionally, the standard deviations of the diameter calculations across the entire trial were all approximately five times smaller than those reported by Griffiths et al.,22 suggesting greater consistency in our measure. This difference also suggests that the standard deviations reported in the aforementioned study could not have been attributable entirely to system error. The renowned accuracy of the motion capture system relies on tracking spherical markers, hence the reason why the markers VICON provides its customers (for calibration and motion capture) are spherical or hemispherical. For this reason, if tape were used, the system would assume that the tape was spherical and calculate its position inaccurately. Therefore, it is possible that the use of pieces of reflective tape as opposed to spherical or hemispherical markers contributed to the larger errors reported by Griffiths et al.22 The drawback of this, however, is that 3D markers will ultimately have some effect on the aerodynamics of the ball. Our opting to use smaller markers with negligible mass was a means to try and minimize this effect.

The error observed in the modelled outputs was minimal in all variables. The small average error observed between the true and modelled elevation angles (0.83 ± 0.74°) validates that the model is able to represent this value accurately. Similarly, an average error of 1.14° (± 0.89°) highlights the validity of the model in depicting the azimuth angle of spin axis. The combination of these modelled outputs verifies that the spin axis of a spinning sphere can be accurately modelled using our method. The modelled angular ball velocity showed minimal error when compared to the true value. The average recorded error of 0.02 rev.s−1suggests that the model provides an accurate representation of the ball’s angular velocity.

One major benefit of this model over its predecessors is the greater flexibility afforded to marker placement. The current model only requires three markers compared to the four that Griffiths et al. proposed as the minimal amount required to model ball rotation.22 Additionally, the model proposed by Griffiths et al. required all four markers be placed in a precise tetrahedral arrangement, the placement of which was suggested to be guided by the panels on a 32-panel soccer ball. Since the publication of the aforementioned article, the design of soccer balls has changed such that 32-panel balls are scarcely produced, in fact the last world cup to feature a 32-panel ball took place in 2002. A further defection of the model proposed by Griffiths et al. is that it is not applicable to other balls, such as cricket balls, tennis balls and baseballs, which do not have readily identifiable tetrahedral surface locations. Without the need for an exact tetrahedral arrangement, and reliant only on precise polar markers, the third marker in the proposed model can be placed arbitrarily depending on the demands of the task and preference of the athlete. In soccer, this would involve leaving a large surface free of markers for contact by the foot. In sports like cricket and baseball the third marker could be positioned so as not to compromise how the athlete would grasp the ball. In this way, the marker placement does not compromise the ecological validity of the task.

The combination of ball translation and rotation, while ecologically relevant, was not validated in this study for justifiable reasons. Bear in mind that only the rotational aspect of the transformation matrices are used in the calculation of rotational kinematics. Therefore, the translational component of the ball’s motion is not directly applicable to the calculation of rotational kinematics. The most critical part of the calculation process is the accurate tracking of the markers. The same is true for any kinematic modelling stemming from 3D motion capture. Therefore, the capability of the system to track the spatial position of 3D markers (not pieces of retro-reflective tape) with great accuracy (error < 0.1 mm) has already been validated and is well documented.18–20 Furthermore, any potential aliasing concerns related to high speed ball movement are addressed by the capability of motion capture systems to record at 2000 Hz. Given that motion capture systems are capable of recording high speed movements with remarkable accuracy, well developed models can be valuable information purveyors. Since the former is well documented, this study only endeavoured to supplement the latter. Worth noting is the fact that the accuracy of the system verifies that tracking the position of the ball origin (as defined in this study) would be an appropriate measure of ball velocity. This study also verified the notion that hemispherical markers on the ball’s surface can be used to compute the ball’s centre with consistency greater than that measured using previous models. Finally, this model has already been used in real-world settings in soccer, cricket and tennis throughout the literature,24–26,29 providing acceptable translational and rotational velocities.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Traditional methods analysing ball motion have often been limited by their instruments or lack of ecological validity and have failed to use the current gold standard in motion analysis. 3D motion capture systems are capable of recording high speed movements with remarkable accuracy, meaning well developed models can be valuable information purveyors. This study highlights how tracking a sports ball using a 3D motion capture system provides a viable but, more importantly, highly accurate alternative to previous approaches. The proposed model has been shown to measure the rotational axes and angular velocities of three different sporting balls with minimal error. The model relies on fewer markers than those previously used in 3D ball tracking, which can be placed in more flexible locations, allowing marker placement to be adjusted according to the skill and without compromising the performer. Furthermore, the model’s ability to calculate the centre of the ball was deemed more consistent than a previously proposed model. The validity of the proposed model affords sports scientists the option to perform more comprehensive analyses of sporting skills in the future, expanding their understanding of the ball’s role in these skills and hopefully yielding practical implications. While the current study measured ball variables using a ball rotating on a stationary drill, it has also been utilized in real world sporting settings, reliably measuring translational and angular velocities.23–25,29 Currently the proposed method is only directly applicable to spherical balls. However, this model could be adapted to ovular balls in the future by altering marker placement. Validation of such a model, in the current manner, would be necessary.

ack.p: The authors wish to thank Wayne Spratford of the Australian Institute of Sport and Dr Alison Alcock of the Sportscotland Institute of Sport for their contributions to this work.
